title: Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome
icd10: unspecified with alcohol-induced persisting amnestic disorder)
F10.26 (Alcohol dependence with alcohol-induced persisting amnestic disorder)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome including the chronic Korsakoff amnestic component, differentiation from isolated Wernicke encephalopathy, long-term cognitive rehabilitation, and nutritional management. Covers transition from acute Wernicke encephalopathy to chronic Korsakoff syndrome, cognitive assessment, pharmacologic and non-pharmacologic interventions for memory impairment, behavioral management, and disposition planning. Applies to ED (acute decompensation/re-presentation), HOSP (initial stabilization and workup), OPD (long-term management and rehabilitation), and ICU (severe cases with hemodynamic or respiratory compromise). For acute Wernicke encephalopathy management, see the dedicated Wernicke Encephalopathy plan.

Refeeding syndrome risk; depleted in malnutrition

Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemia from malnutrition/liver disease; give thiamine before dextrose
Document active use; assess withdrawal risk; guide management
Baseline thiamine status; low levels support diagnosis but do not delay treatment

Hypothyroidism may contribute to cognitive impairment and must be excluded
Neurosyphilis can cause cognitive decline and amnesia; must exclude in at-risk patients

Liver synthetic function; coagulopathy risk in alcohol-related liver disease
Identify concurrent substance use affecting cognition and behavior
Chronic glycemic control; diabetes contributes to cognitive impairment and neuropathy
Deficiency common in alcohol use and malnutrition; contributes to bone health and cognitive function

>25% increase after TPP addition indicates deficiency; more sensitive than total thiamine
Differentiates B12 deficiency from folate deficiency; relevant to cognitive impairment

Essential Neuroimaging.timing: Within 24-48 hours of presentation; or at initial outpatient evaluation
Essential Neuroimaging.target: Bilateral symmetric T2/FLAIR hyperintensity in mammillary bodies, medial thalami, periaqueductal gray; mammillary body atrophy in chronic KS; cortical atrophy; cerebellar vermis atrophy

Essential Neuroimaging.timing: Immediate if altered mental status; exclude hemorrhage, mass, hydrocephalus
Essential Neuroimaging.target: No acute hemorrhage or mass; may show cerebral atrophy; often normal in WKS

Extended Imaging.target: Mammillary body volume loss; thalamic atrophy; frontal cortical thinning; hippocampal atrophy

Extended Imaging.item: CT head without contrast (if MRI unavailable)
Extended Imaging.timing: Acute setting when MRI not feasible
Extended Imaging.target: Cerebral atrophy; thalamic hypodensity (rare); exclude other pathology

Additional Studies.timing: If seizure suspected or unexplained encephalopathy
Additional Studies.target: Diffuse slowing (non-specific); rule out non-convulsive status epilepticus

Additional Studies.timing: Consider if atypical dementia pattern; research/specialist evaluation
Additional Studies.target: Bilateral thalamic and frontal hypometabolism in KS

Additional Studies.timing: After acute phase resolves; outpatient baseline and serial assessment
Additional Studies.target: Severe anterograde amnesia; impaired executive function; relative preservation of procedural memory and IQ
Additional Studies.contraindications: Requires patient cooperation; unreliable if acutely confused

dosing.instructions: 1 tablet PO daily; indefinite

Cognitive and Behavioral Pharmacotherapy.indication: Cholinergic augmentation for memory impairment in Korsakoff syndrome; limited but suggestive evidence of benefit in alcohol-related cognitive impairment

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO daily x 4-6 weeks; increase to 10 mg daily if tolerated; assess cognitive response at 3 months

Cognitive and Behavioral Pharmacotherapy.contraindications: Sick sinus syndrome; AV block; active GI bleeding; severe COPD/asthma
Cognitive and Behavioral Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: Heart rate (bradycardia); GI symptoms (nausea, diarrhea); weight; MMSE or MoCA at baseline and q3-6 months

Cognitive and Behavioral Pharmacotherapy.indication: NMDA receptor antagonist for moderate-severe cognitive impairment; may reduce excitotoxicity in alcohol-related brain damage

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO daily; increase by 5 mg/week; target 10 mg BID; max 20 mg/day

Cognitive and Behavioral Pharmacotherapy.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (CrCl <30); concurrent use of other NMDA antagonists
Cognitive and Behavioral Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: Renal function; confusion; dizziness; cognitive assessment q3-6 months

Cognitive and Behavioral Pharmacotherapy.indication: Depression and apathy commonly comorbid in Korsakoff syndrome; SSRI with evidence in alcohol-related depression

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg PO daily; increase by 25-50 mg q1-2 weeks; target 50-150 mg daily; max 200 mg/day

Cognitive and Behavioral Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: Suicidality in first weeks; sodium (SIADH risk); GI bleeding risk with concurrent NSAIDs; mood and function assessment

Cognitive and Behavioral Pharmacotherapy.indication: Depression with insomnia, poor appetite, and weight loss in Korsakoff syndrome; promotes appetite and sleep

dosing.instructions: Start 7.5-15 mg PO qHS; increase by 15 mg q1-2 weeks; max 45 mg qHS; more sedating at lower doses

Cognitive and Behavioral Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: Weight; metabolic panel; sedation; mood assessment

Cognitive and Behavioral Pharmacotherapy.indication: Insomnia and sleep-wake cycle disruption common in Korsakoff syndrome; avoids benzodiazepine dependence risk

dosing.instructions: Start 25-50 mg PO qHS; titrate by 25-50 mg q3-5 days; max 200 mg qHS for insomnia

Cognitive and Behavioral Pharmacotherapy.contraindications: Priapism risk (rare); concurrent MAOIs; severe hepatic impairment
Cognitive and Behavioral Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: Orthostatic hypotension; excessive sedation; priapism (counsel patient)

Cognitive and Behavioral Pharmacotherapy.indication: Agitation, psychosis, or severe behavioral disturbance in Korsakoff syndrome not responsive to non-pharmacologic measures

dosing.instructions: Start 12.5-25 mg PO BID; titrate slowly by 25 mg q3-5 days; max 200 mg/day; use lowest effective dose

Cognitive and Behavioral Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: Metabolic panel; HbA1c; QTc; extrapyramidal symptoms; falls; sedation; annual movement disorder screening

dosing.instructions: 0.5-2 mg IV/IM q4-6h PRN agitation; max 10 mg/day; switch to oral/atypical ASAP

Cognitive and Behavioral Pharmacotherapy.contraindications: QTc prolongation; Parkinsonism; dementia-related psychosis (FDA black box); neuroleptic malignant syndrome
Cognitive and Behavioral Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: QTc monitoring; extrapyramidal symptoms; sedation level; vital signs

Alcohol Use Disorder Treatment.indication: Adjunctive treatment for alcohol craving and insomnia; reduces alcohol consumption; also treats concurrent neuropathic pain

Alcohol Withdrawal Management (If Presen.monitoring: CIWA score; sedation level; hepatic function; respiratory status

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consult for diagnosis confirmation, differentiation from other dementias, and long-term cognitive management planning
Neuropsychology referral for formal cognitive assessment including memory, executive function, and functional capacity evaluation
Addiction medicine or psychiatry consult for alcohol use disorder treatment, relapse prevention, and dual-diagnosis management
Physical therapy for gait training, balance rehabilitation, and fall prevention given persistent cerebellar ataxia
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, compensatory strategy training, and memory aid implementation for daily functioning
Speech-language pathology for cognitive-linguistic assessment, memory strategy training, and swallowing evaluation if dysphagia present
Social work for discharge planning, residential placement assessment, guardianship evaluation, and community resource coordination
Nutrition/dietitian consult for nutritional rehabilitation, meal planning, and ongoing supplementation guidance
Cognitive rehabilitation specialist for errorless learning protocols, spaced retrieval training, and compensatory memory strategy development
Palliative care consult for goals of care discussion in patients with severe irreversible Korsakoff syndrome and significant functional impairment

Patient and Family Instructions.item: Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome causes brain damage from thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, usually related to alcohol use; the memory problems may be permanent but can stabilize with treatment
Take thiamine supplements exactly as prescribed every day; missing doses can worsen brain damage
Complete abstinence from alcohol is essential to prevent further brain injury and allow maximum recovery
Memory problems may make it difficult to remember medications; use pill organizers, phone alarms, and caregiver reminders
Return to the emergency department immediately if confusion worsens, new vision problems develop, or walking becomes significantly more unsteady (may indicate acute decompensation)
Do not drive or operate heavy machinery until formally evaluated by neurology and neuropsychology due to cognitive impairment and impaired judgment
Eat regular balanced meals including foods high in thiamine (whole grains, legumes, pork, nuts); malnutrition worsens symptoms
The confabulation (making up stories without realizing it) is part of the illness and is not intentional lying; families should gently redirect rather than confront
SAMHSA National Helpline 1-800-662-4357 for free alcohol treatment referrals and information
Caregivers should attend follow-up appointments to provide collateral history and receive education on disease management

Lifestyle and Rehabilitation.item: Absolute alcohol abstinence to prevent further thiamine depletion and progressive neuronal damage
Structured daily routine with consistent mealtimes, medication times, and activities to support residual memory function through procedural learning
Environmental modifications including written schedules posted in visible locations, labeled rooms and drawers, and simplified living space to reduce cognitive demand
Fall prevention measures including non-skid footwear, removal of home hazards, grab bars in bathroom, and assistive device use given persistent gait ataxia
Supervised medication administration by caregiver or structured program given inability to reliably self-administer due to anterograde amnesia
Cognitive stimulation through structured activities (puzzles, music therapy, reminiscence therapy) to promote engagement and maintain existing cognitive function
Nutritional counseling with high-thiamine diet including whole grains, enriched cereals, legumes, lean pork, nuts, and seeds
Supervised community living or structured residential placement if unable to live independently due to cognitive impairment and safety concerns
Caregiver respite resources and support groups to prevent caregiver burnout given high care burden of chronic amnestic syndrome
Regular exercise program adapted to functional level to improve cardiovascular health, mood, and maintain mobility

differential.features: Gradual onset; temporal lobe atrophy on MRI; amyloid/tau biomarkers positive; no alcohol history required; hippocampal atrophy predominates
differential.tests: MRI volumetrics; CSF amyloid-beta/tau; PET amyloid imaging

differential.features: Asterixis; elevated ammonia; liver disease; fluctuating course; reversible with lactulose/rifaximin
differential.tests: Ammonia level; LFTs; liver imaging; clinical response to treatment

differential.features: Stepwise decline; focal neurological signs; vascular risk factors; white matter disease on imaging
differential.tests: MRI (lacunar infarcts, periventricular white matter changes); vascular risk profile

differential.features: Global cognitive decline without disproportionate amnesia; cortical atrophy; no confabulation
differential.tests: Neuropsychological testing shows global pattern vs. disproportionate amnesia in KS; MRI pattern differs

differential.features: History of acute febrile encephalitis; temporal lobe necrosis on MRI; anterograde amnesia can be similar
differential.tests: MRI (temporal lobe signal changes); CSF HSV PCR history; temporal lobe atrophy

differential.features: Sudden onset; resolves within 24 hours; no confusion or confabulation after resolution; single episode
differential.tests: Clinical course (self-resolving); DWI may show hippocampal restriction

differential.features: Triad of gait apraxia, urinary incontinence, and dementia; ventriculomegaly out of proportion to atrophy
differential.tests: MRI (enlarged ventricles, tight sulci); large-volume LP trial with gait assessment pre/post

differential.features: Subacute onset; seizures; psychiatric symptoms; antibody-mediated; may respond to immunotherapy
differential.tests: Autoimmune encephalitis antibody panel (LGI1, CASPR2, NMDAR); CSF analysis; MRI medial temporal signal

differential.features: Progressive cognitive/behavioral decline; history of repetitive head trauma; no specific biomarker
differential.tests: Clinical history of head trauma; diagnosis of exclusion; confirmed only on autopsy

differential.features: Personality change and behavioral disinhibition predominate; executive dysfunction; frontal atrophy
differential.tests: Neuropsychological profile; MRI (frontal/temporal atrophy pattern); FDG-PET

differential.features: Temporal correlation with medication changes; reversible with discontinuation
differential.tests: Medication reconciliation; improvement after dose reduction or discontinuation

evidence.recommendation: High-dose IV thiamine (500 mg TID) for WE treatment and prevention of Korsakoff syndrome
evidence.source: [Galvin R et al. Cochrane Database Syst Rev 2010](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20614462/); [Thomson AD et al. Alcohol Alcohol 2002](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12414541/)

evidence.recommendation: Korsakoff syndrome develops in approximately 80% of untreated or inadequately treated WE cases
evidence.source: [Victor M, Adams RD, Collins GH. The Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome and Related Neurologic Disorders Due to Alcoholism and Malnutrition. 1989](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2667707/)

evidence.recommendation: MRI findings (mammillary body atrophy, thalamic signal changes) support WKS diagnosis
evidence.source: [Zuccoli G et al. AJNR Am J Neuroradiol 2007](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17893203/); [Sullivan EV, Pfefferbaum A. Neuropsychol Rev 2009](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19184444/)

evidence.recommendation: Errorless learning and spaced retrieval techniques improve functional outcomes in Korsakoff syndrome
Cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil) show limited but suggestive benefit in alcohol-related cognitive impairment
Oral thiamine has limited bioavailability in patients with alcohol use disorder; parenteral route preferred
Magnesium is essential cofactor for thiamine pyrophosphokinase; replacement critical for thiamine efficacy
Naltrexone and acamprosate reduce alcohol relapse; critical for preventing WKS progression
Neuropsychological profile of Korsakoff syndrome: disproportionate amnesia with relatively preserved IQ and procedural memory
EFNS guidelines for diagnosis and management of Wernicke encephalopathy
evidence.source: [Galvin R et al. Eur J Neurol 2010](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20236172/)

evidence.recommendation: Recovery from Korsakoff syndrome: approximately 25% show significant improvement with adequate treatment and abstinence

disposition.criteria: Suspected acute Wernicke encephalopathy requiring IV thiamine; new-onset confusion in known WKS patient; severe malnutrition requiring supervised refeeding; active alcohol withdrawal
Altered mental status with hemodynamic instability; severe alcohol withdrawal (CIWA >20 or seizures); respiratory compromise; refeeding syndrome with electrolyte instability
Hemodynamically stable; CIWA <10 or withdrawal resolved; tolerating oral intake; no ongoing electrolyte instability
Medically stable; persistent cognitive and functional deficits requiring intensive rehabilitation; unable to safely manage at home; requires supervised medication administration
Chronic stable KS with persistent amnesia; unable to live independently; requires structured environment with medication management and meal supervision
Medically stable; reliable caregiver available 24/7; caregiver educated on medication administration, safety precautions, and return triggers; outpatient follow-up arranged
Mild residual deficits only; demonstrated medication compliance capability; adequate nutrition independently; alcohol abstinence maintained; stable housing; outpatient follow-up arranged
2-4 weeks post-discharge for cognitive reassessment; then q3-6 months for longitudinal monitoring
Within 1-2 weeks of discharge if alcohol use disorder present; ongoing relapse prevention program
Acute confusion or cognitive decline; suspected relapse with malnutrition; inability to maintain oral intake or medication compliance; new neurological symptoms
